prompt:
Given the pseudocode below, perform a rigorous and systematic evaluation of its reproducibility. Specifically, determine whether the pseudocode is:

- **Complete:** all variables, data structures, and operations are fully defined and initialized without implicit assumptions.
- **Unambiguous:** every step and condition clearly indicates the intended logic with no vague or contradictory instructions.
- **Logically consistent:** the control flow, loops, and conditionals form a coherent algorithm correctly implementing the intended functionality.
- **Self-contained:** it relies solely on its own definitions and steps, has no dependencies on unspecified external functions or information.
- **Robust:** it accounts for edge cases and handles all typical inputs relevant to its purpose.

Assess if this pseudocode, as given, can be translated into executable code that **unfailingly passes all comprehensive unit tests designed for the stated problem**—i.e., it correctly solves the problem for all inputs within the input domain.

**Important:**

- Only evaluate the pseudocode’s specification, not the original problem statement or hidden assumptions.
- Ignore style or language nuance; focus strictly on functional reproducibility.
- The output must be exactly `1` if it meets all criteria above — fully specified, unambiguous, logically sound, and test-complete; output `0` otherwise.
- Return **only** the single digit `1` or `0` and nothing else.

Pseudocode:
```
{pseudocode here}
```
response:

feedback:
We have a 2 way split for the pseudocodes: true positives, which are pseudocodes that correspond to code that passes all test cases.
We also have true negatives, which are pseudocodes that correspond to code that do not pass all test cases.
The following are pseudocodes that are reproducible but were labeled as not:
CLASS Solution  
    FUNCTION longestPalindrome(s)  
        SET n TO the LENGTH OF s  
        SET f TO a TWO DIMENSIONAL LIST of BOOLEAN TRUES with n ROWS and n COLUMNS  
        SET k TO zero  
        SET mx TO one  
        FOR i FROM n MINUS two DOWN TO zero  
            FOR j FROM i PLUS one TO n MINUS one  
                SET element at position i and position j of f TO FALSE  
                IF element at position i of s EQUALS element at position j of s  
                    SET element at position i and position j of f TO element at position i PLUS one and position j MINUS one of f  
                    IF element at position i and position j of f EQUALS TRUE AND mx LESS THAN j MINUS i PLUS one  
                        SET k TO i  
                        SET mx TO j MINUS i PLUS one  
                    END IF  
                END IF  
            END FOR  
        END FOR  
        RETURN substring from position k TO position k PLUS mx MINUS one of s  
    END FUNCTION  
END CLASS
CLASS Solution  
    FUNCTION multiply(num1 string num2 string) RETURNS string  
        IF num1 EQUALS string zero OR num2 EQUALS string zero  
            RETURN string zero  
        END IF  

        SET result TO a list of zeros with the LENGTH OF num1 PLUS the LENGTH OF num2  

        SET num1 TO the reversal of num1  
        SET num2 TO the reversal of num2  

        FOR i FROM zero TO the LENGTH OF num1 MINUS one  
            FOR j FROM zero TO the LENGTH OF num2 MINUS one  
                SET mul TO the character code of the element at position i of num1 MINUS the character code of string zero MULTIPLIED BY the character code of the element at position j of num2 MINUS the character code of string zero  
                SET p1 TO i PLUS j  
                SET p2 TO i PLUS j PLUS one  
                SET sum TO mul PLUS the element at position p1 of result  

                SET the element at position p1 of result TO sum MODULO ten  
                INCREMENT the element at position p2 of result BY the integer division of sum BY ten  
            END FOR  
        END FOR  

        SET result_str TO the concatenation of the string representations of the elements of result in reverse order  
        RETURN result_str with all leading string zeros removed  
    END FUNCTION  
END CLASS
CLASS Solution  
    FUNCTION isMatch(s, p)  
        SET dp TO a two dimensional list of False with the number of rows equal to the length of s PLUS one and the number of columns equal to the length of p PLUS one  
        SET element at position zero zero of dp TO True  
        FOR j FROM one TO the length of p  
            IF element at position j MINUS one of p EQUALS the character representing asterisk  
                SET element at position zero j of dp TO the value of element at position zero j MINUS one of dp  
            END IF  
        END FOR  
        FOR i FROM one TO the length of s  
            FOR j FROM one TO the length of p  
                IF element at position j MINUS one of p EQUALS the character representing asterisk  
                    SET element at position i j of dp TO the value of element at position i MINUS one j of dp OR the value of element at position i j MINUS one of dp  
                ELSE IF element at position j MINUS one of p EQUALS the character representing question mark OR element at position i MINUS one of s EQUALS element at position j MINUS one of p  
                    SET element at position i j of dp TO the value of element at position i MINUS one j MINUS one of dp  
                END IF  
            END FOR  
        END FOR  
        RETURN element at position the length of s the length of p of dp  
    END FUNCTION  
END CLASS
CLASS Solution  
    FUNCTION uniquePaths(m n)  
        SET dp TO a two dimensional list with m rows and n columns where each element is set to one  
        FOR i FROM two TO m  
            FOR j FROM two TO n  
                SET element at position i of dp TO the list at position i of dp  
                SET element at position j of element at position i of dp TO the sum of the element at position i MINUS one of dp at position j AND the element at position i of dp at position j MINUS one  
            END FOR  
        END FOR  
        RETURN the element at position m MINUS one of dp at position n MINUS one  
    END FUNCTION  
END CLASS

The following are pseudocodes that are not reproducible but were labeled as reproducible:
```
SET INT_MAX = 2^31 - 1, INT_MIN = -2^31
INIT res = 0, i = 0, n = len(s), sign = 1
WHILE i < n AND s[i] = ' ' : i += 1
IF i < n AND s[i] IN ['+', '-'] : sign = -1 IF s[i] = '-' ELSE 1; i += 1
WHILE i < n AND s[i].isdigit():
    d = int(s[i])
    IF res > (INT_MAX - d)//10: RETURN INT_MAX IF sign = 1 ELSE INT_MIN
    res = res*10 + d
    i += 1
RETURN sign * res
```
Here is a version of the pseudocode that IS reproducible:
CLASS Solution  
    FUNCTION myAtoi(s)  
        SET INT_MAX TO two RAISED TO THE POWER OF thirty ONE MINUS one  
        SET INT_MIN TO the NEGATIVE of two RAISED TO THE POWER OF thirty ONE  
        SET result TO zero  
        SET index TO zero  
        SET n TO the LENGTH OF s  
        SET sign TO one  
        WHILE index LESS THAN n AND element at position index of s EQUALS the space character  
            INCREMENT index BY one  
        END WHILE  
        IF index LESS THAN n AND (element at position index of s EQUALS the plus character OR element at position index of s EQUALS the minus character)  
            IF element at position index of s EQUALS the minus character  
                SET sign TO the NEGATIVE of one  
            ELSE  
                SET sign TO one  
            END IF  
            INCREMENT index BY one  
        END IF  
        WHILE index LESS THAN n AND element at position index of s IS A DIGIT  
            SET digit TO the INTEGER VALUE OF element at position index of s  
            IF result GREATER THAN INT_MAX MINUS digit DIVIDED BY ten  
                IF sign EQUALS one  
                    RETURN INT_MAX  
                ELSE  
                    RETURN INT_MIN  
                END IF  
            END IF  
            SET result TO result MULTIPLIED BY ten PLUS digit  
            INCREMENT index BY one  
        END WHILE  
        RETURN sign MULTIPLIED BY result  
    END FUNCTION  
END CLASS
CLASS Solution
    FUNCTION canJump(list_of_numbers)
        SET farthest_reachable_index TO zero
        FOR index FROM zero TO the LENGTH OF list_of_numbers MINUS one INCLUSIVE
            IF index GREATER THAN farthest_reachable_index
                RETURN False
            END IF
            SET possible_reach TO index PLUS element at position index OF list_of_numbers
            SET farthest_reachable_index TO the GREATER OF farthest_reachable_index AND possible_reach
        END FOR
        RETURN farthest_reachable_index GREATER THAN OR EQUAL TO the LENGTH OF list_of_numbers MINUS one
    END FUNCTION
END CLASS
Here is a version of the pseudocode that IS reproducible:
CLASS Solution  
    FUNCTION canJump(nums)  
        SET farthest TO zero  
        FOR i FROM zero TO the LENGTH OF nums MINUS one  
            IF i GREATER THAN farthest  
                RETURN false  
            END IF  
            SET possible_reach TO i PLUS element at position i of nums  
            IF possible_reach GREATER THAN farthest  
                SET farthest TO possible_reach  
            END IF  
        END FOR  
        IF farthest GREATER THAN OR EQUAL TO the LENGTH OF nums MINUS one  
            RETURN true  
        ELSE  
            RETURN false  
        END IF  
    END FUNCTION  
END CLASS

```
dp = [[1]*n for _ in range(m)]
for i in 1 to m-1:
  for j in 1 to n-1:
    dp[i][j] = dp[i-1][j] + dp[i][j-1]
return dp[m-1][n-1]
```

        FOR i FROM two TO m  
            FOR j FROM two TO n  
                SET element at position i of dp TO the list at position i of dp  
                SET element at position j of element at position i of dp TO the sum of the element at position i MINUS one of dp at position j AND the element at position i of dp at position j MINUS one

```
define combine(n, k):
  result = []
  define backtrack(start, path):
    if len(path) = k:
      result.append(copy of path)
      return
    for i in range(start to n):
      path.append(i)
      backtrack(i+1, path)
      path.pop()
  backtrack(1, [])
  return result
```
Here is a version of the pseudocode that IS reproducible:
CLASS Solution  
    FUNCTION combine WITH PARAMETERS n k  
        FUNCTION backtrack WITH PARAMETERS start path  
            IF the LENGTH OF path EQUALS k  
                APPEND a COPY OF path TO result  
                RETURN  
            END IF  
            FOR i FROM start TO n PLUS one  
                APPEND i TO path  
                CALL backtrack WITH ARGUMENTS i PLUS one path  
                REMOVE the LAST ELEMENT FROM path  
            END FOR  
        END FUNCTION  
        SET result TO an EMPTY LIST  
        CALL backtrack WITH ARGUMENTS one AN EMPTY LIST  
        RETURN result  
    END FUNCTION  
END CLASS
